title: Looking for wooden/decorative type
content:
I’m looking for wooden/decorative type similar to the white text in the H&F-J logo on their site. Anything similar to this style would we very useful. I’ve trawled through dafont and a few other free font sites and haven’t been able to find anything useful. Could really use some help.

Cheers

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20081122032835im_/http:/www.typophile.com/files/Picture_1_5452.jpg)

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20081122032835im_/http:/www.typophile.com/files/Picture_2_5827.jpg)

 [‹ (x) Which Didot is this? - Linotype Didot {Jan E}](http://web.archive.org/web/20081122032835/http:/www.typophile.com/node/47757 "Go to previous forum topic") [Looking for a solid version of the Sinaloa display face ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20081122032835/http:/www.typophile.com/node/47768 "Go to next forum topic")
author: smongey

comments.content:
Hi Seán,

<cite>The ornate “H&FJ” in the background of our logo isn’t a typeface, it’s a piece of lettering created by Jonathan Hoefler.</cite> — [http://www.typography.com/ask/topics.php?topicID=13#Faq\_107](http://web.archive.org/web/20081122032835/http:/www.typography.com/ask/topics.php?topicID=13#Faq_107 "http://www.typography.com/ask/topics.php?topicID=13#Faq\_107")

You might find something of use in this thread: [Circus Fonts and Wild West Fonts](http://web.archive.org/web/20081122032835/http:/typophile.com/node/12892).  
Furthermore: [Madame](http://web.archive.org/web/20081122032835/http:/www.linotype.com/en/5221/madame.html). And some freebies, for good measure: [Egyptienne Zierinitialen](http://web.archive.org/web/20081122032835/http:/www.moorstation.org/typoasis/designers/steffmann/samples/e/egyptzier.htm)/ [Romantiques](http://web.archive.org/web/20081122032835/http:/moorstation.org/typoasis/designers/steffmann/samples/r/romantiques.htm), [Ringmaster](http://web.archive.org/web/20081122032835/http:/www.moorstation.org/typoasis/designers/jfs/ringmaster.html).  
F

Thanks Florian,

As always, very helpful :)

Also see Paul Barnes’ “Classics” :

[http://moderntypography.com/Typedesign/Classics/index.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20081122032835/http:/moderntypography.com/Typedesign/Classics/index.html "http://moderntypography.com/Typedesign/Classics/index.html")

and at

[http://www.stbridetype.com/](http://web.archive.org/web/20081122032835/http:/www.stbridetype.com/ "http://www.stbridetype.com/")

...and don’t forget to look at some real wood type stuff, please:

[http://www.bleisetzer.de/cms/front\_content.php?idcat=42](http://web.archive.org/web/20081122032835/http:/www.bleisetzer.de/cms/front_content.php?idcat=42 "http://www.bleisetzer.de/cms/front\_content.php?idcat=42")

Regards,

Georg  
\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_  
„Ich bin ein Preuße, kennt Ihr meine Farben...“
The german free fonts are awesome. Thanks Florian.

You’re welcome.  
I’m not so sure about them being awesome. They may serve _some_ purposes, but usually, decorative wood typefaces like these have to be tall to unfold their full glory – and at bigger sizes, the shortcomings of these digitizations become visible.
